caption: Do not come hungry! You will be waiting a while for each dish and fill yourself up on the free white rice.  Food is a bit too spicy too.  Disappointing.
Amazing food, delicious cocktails and warm outdoor private tent
Went to Astoria for my birthday dinner. It was fantastic. Nothing beats fresh, home-made noodles!!

Delicious. Did pick up so didn't have any service  interactions. Website claimed it would take 45 min. Took 11 minutes. MaPo tofu was stellar. Big portion. Dan dan was lovely. It's more expensive than the greasy Chinese, but absolutely worth it. If every item was closer in size to the MaPo, I'd go there every other night.
Spicy food, but delicious! Great cocktails too.

This is easily, one of my favorite restaurants in DC. No matter what I am in the mood for, this place has been a life-saver. Absolutely incredible options for food, drink, and appetizers. Would definitely recommend to anyone in the area.

Great food, outstanding bar program, friendliest staff on all of 17th street. A must try. Food tends to be on the spicy side so definitely a must try for those who like it got. They also have a few milder options but every single dish out if they kitchen is excellent. The bar team also mixes vermouth for an outstanding blend. I recommend a Mezcal Negroni.

They don't tone down their spices or flavors to appeal to bland flavor palettes which I appreciate. I typically don't gravitate towards fish dishes but I really liked their water boiled fish with sichuan peppercorns. Solid cocktails too.
Great restaurant! Especially during CoviD-19! 10 Stars!!

Perfect patio for eating outside at night. Every dish and drink was made to perfection. The wait staff was efficient and made us feel very welcomed. I had the wings, beef noodles, and Dan Dan noodles. I could put the baked apple toddy down or my Moscow mule. I highly recommend.

Astoria has become one of my favorite neighborhood bars/restaurants. I can always count on their friendly bartenders to pour some delicious cocktails. The outdoor terrace seating is wonderful and has such nice ambiance in the evening. A great spot for catching up with friends after a long day or just for people watching on the weekends. As far as the food goes, I’ve only tried the walnut shrimp but it’s so good I keep coming back for the same thing😂
Food was great, definitely worth it. For prices, service was not as attentive as it could be

Astoria is simply amazing.  It quickly became my most frequented spot in DuPont as I love spicy food. If you do too, you have to get the water boiled beef. All variations of the fried rice are great too, and combine really nicely with the veggie triple delight.  On the sweeter side, the walnut shrimp are very tasty. They also have a fantastic cocktail menu that is unique and updated frequently.  The management and service staff are top notch and in our 10+ visits we have never been disappointed.

Astoria is fantastic, especially for a date night. The drinks are amazing and the menu is unique in the best way. Lots of options for spice lovers (especially the water boiled beef) but also for those not great with spiciness like myself. I love the walnut shrimp and combining the veggie triple delight + the fried rice. Service is top notch, especially Chu. Outdoor seating and social distancing precautions were greatly appreciated. Definitely recommend!
Very good food. Cocktails were good. Choice of music and volume were atrocious. Do not order red wine, it is awful.

We have done carryout from Astoria twice and we love this place. The mapo tofu and the water boiled beef are game changers. However, if you have a problem with spicy food, you may want to ask them to tone down the spicyness. Most of their dishes are hot.

Great drinks, the goldfish snack was unique. The service was slow and the food was definitely spicy (which is great!). However, the  sweet and sour ribs was pretty much all vinegar...so not the best. Overall the menu is small and solid, maybe just got a bad batch of the ribs.
Great good, great service, great music, great ambiance. Happy I stumbled into this restaurant. I will surely return.

Fun little restaurant in a row of several others in Dupont Circle.  The food was fine, spicy but we are used to spicier but this was fine.  Did not feel any MSG buzz (that was a plus), well portioned, only bother was a pesky fly.  We went a couple of weeks ago, so weather was perfect for outside.  We ordered several of their signature cocktails, light not heavy on booze.  Service attentive.  Great for flip flops, easy chill dinner.  I'd definitely go back.

Great food, bad music/ambience. Went there this weekend and sat inside. The food was good, but the music playing was distracting and terrible. When I am dining during a night out, I don't want to compete with loud hip hop music in order to hear the dinner guest sitting across from me.  It felt like I was eating food in a bar rather than a more sophisticated restaurant. I will go back, I just hope the music stays home.
Its really good
Waited 30 minutes  over the estimated  time for pickup.  Horrible takeout service. I will never order from here again. Dine at you're own risk.

this is the best Chinese food ever. FINALLY a clean and authentic cuisine. True Sichuan.  GET THE WATER BOILED BEEF AND THE LAZI CHICKEN OH and the crab fried rice. This is all incredible. Its priced high but it's so good. so good.  Don't expect platters of food. This is a mindful portion but absolutely worth it.

The food is undoubted amazing but here’s the trick - Everything is $15 dollars each - the drinks and the appetizers and the entrees.  So a bigger entree is the same price as a small appetizer- which seems unfair.  A chili wonton is $15 versus a Walnut shrimp.  So if u r savvy, I would stick with the larger entrees and skip the drinks as the drinks were definitely not worth $15.  The flavors are amazing and authentic. The service - we sat outside was very good. They had someone stationed outside and he was very attentive.  Tall white guy.  Also a note - it’s super spicy - anything in the description that says Chilli oil is very spicy, so stay away from those if you r not into it.  The location is great and we had a great time.  All the restaurants now post covid have tables outside and even right on 17th.

The food is absolutely delicious. The drinks are absolutely phenomenal. The water boiled fish was painful in the best way, and I'm happy to get unlimited rice to help make it tolerable. (I recommend sharing the pain with friends rather than punishing yourself alone.) I will always return to this place!
Try the Ma Po Tofu and Water Boiled Beef!

Astoria DC was even better than I hoped. On a recent trip to Belize we met a couple from DC and they suggested we visit two restaurants on our upcoming long weekend in Washington. Astoria DC was one and it was truly a memorable experience. We arrived early around 6 and tables were already full - larger groups were being placed on a call back list and the two of us were promptly accommodated at limited standing room at the bar to await a private table. We were offered the option of seats at a communal table also. Prompt service from one of the many bartenders provided a Bourbon Smash and Moscow Mule.  As soon as the table for 2 opened we were quickly seated and proffered dinner menus and suggestions from our bartender who also served as our waitress.  Moving to classic Old Fashioned with Dan Dan noodles and spicy Chili Wontons to start followed by mild but tasty Walnut Shrimp and very spicy La Zi Chicken with rice to temper the heat.  Excellent cocktails, phenomenal food and service - wishing Dallas had more unique and eclectic places like this.
Great food and great drinks

We were really hopeful for this place - the interior train car look was lovely and really cozy and the food looked like it had fantastic potential.  TL;DR - food was bland, portions were tiny for $14 each. Good atmosphere, cute space.  The dan dan noodles were great - the noodle texture was perfect and it had a mildly numbing spiciness. The only complaint is that the bowl was pretty small only 4-5 mouthfuls of noodles.  The eggplant was fantastic in texture but oh so incredibly BLAND. Like it felt like I was just eating crispy fried oil that was the only flavor I got from it. Eggplant in Chinese cuisine is traditionally cooked with garlic, some sort of chili oil, light & dark soy sauce with a bit of sugar for flavor but I could only really taste oil in this dish, not even the basil. The texture gave me such high hopes because eggplant can be quite a difficult vegetable to cook.  The water boiled beef was ok. There was more flavor but it was still a bit bland, and the peppercorn dominated the flavor so much that there weren’t really many other flavor profiles. In addition there were only like 6 pieces of beef in the whole thing..?  Also the dishes came out one at a time and not close enough together and in a useful order, like the blandness of the eggplant might have been better if I could dipped it in the sauce/broth of the water boiled beef but by the time we had finished the eggplant we had to a wait a bit before the beef had come out.  Overall probably wouldn’t go back unless I was in the area and had an insatiable craving for Dan Dan noodles.

Very nice staff, cool ambiance, but entirely forgettable food. The Dan Dan Mian were nicely spiced, but they were uncharacteristically dry and overpriced at $14. Meh wontons, passable fried rice and frankly gross shrimp with walnuts. If you want good Chinese, head to MD or VA and dine much better for half the price. However, if you just want to sit somewhere fancy and have a drink, this might do the trick.

We went on a Saturday night and yeah the wait is long but so worth it. Great portions for sharing between 2 with good sized delicious cocktails. The staff was also friendly and checked in frequently. Definitely going back

What a great addition to 17th Street! The spot is somewhat hidden and out of the way, but the drinks great and so is the food. Everything is $14. I haven't had a bad experience. Feel free to order cocktails off the menu, or bartenders choice.
Great little Asian restaurant, dishes are mostly a spin on the Chinese classics. La Tzi Ji Chicken, basil eggplant and water boiled beef are my favorites
Rude staff!! We couldn’t even try food or drinks because they asked us to stand by the door in a rude way till we get seated while checking the place out!
Definitely a top notch DC restaurant. Food is perfect cocktails are great.
Great Dan Dan Noodles and Chimichuri. The spice level is perfect some dishes may pack the heat but usually the right level. The drinks are also amazing and cannot be beat.

Came here sitting for 20mins, no menu or any service but waiting. Idk what they doing, cool. Fake 4.6 I guess? Ha. Came here all the way in the winter bcz the high review.  they are like they dont care, they just so Cool. Ok. Ha congratulations, my 1st 1 star ever

I've been here at least once a month since they opened in the summer and have had outstanding experiences each time, and it has easily risen to one of my top 3 restaurants/bars in the city. The drinks are ALL good. I don't normally drink more than 1 drink, and find myself ordering 2 or 3 each time I'm here because they're that good.  Food is also always amazing, and very very similar to the Szechuan food I grew up eating. Get the water boiled beef. Just do it. It's not as spicy as you think it is because it's 'mala', or numbing, rather than a hot spicy. i've brought friends who couldn't eat a lot of spicy foods and they have all loved this dish. In fact, order everything on the menu because it's just that good.  Staff are always friendly and helpful with the menu, as well! Come here early on the weekends to avoid a wait, but even if you have to wait, it's well worth it.
I would give Astoria 6 stars if I could. Everything here is delicious. The MaPo tofu is incredible and so are the chili wontons. Amazing food, service, and drinks.
I tried this spot already with my friend and I am hooked since then. I liked the awesome ambience and flavorful dishes and beverages. 5 stars from me.
So bomb! Servers are great and are very attentive. Food is amazing, great flavors with certain dishes having some spiciness. Cute, small bar feel with amazing drinks. Definitely coming back!

We enjoyed a nice dinner here on Saturday night. We were able to get a table for six around 6pm. They don’t take reservations. The space is dimly lit and moody. It can get a little loud inside with music and conversation. The drinks and food were quite good. The dishes are somewhat small but packed with flavor and cooked well. We were able to share several dishes in our party. We got free goldfish crackers as a snack. I liked the mapo tofu, the chicken, and the shrimp (if you’re into walnut shrimp). Like the rest of the space, the bathroom is tiled and  decorated with ornate features.
Great cocktails, good food and friendly staff!

I'm biased because I love spicy food. This bar features Sichuan food that is adapted to a more western taste, making dishes more aromatic, less numbing and spicy. Cocktails are delicious. I'd recommend water-boiled beef and chicken wings for those who love spicy food; mapo tofu for those who can't take too much spice. My only advice is don't go with the dan dan noodles - it's the one dish I think it doesn't do well. Definitely worth going back (for multiple times).

The food is great but they don’t take reservations and with all the dining options nearby and peoples busy schedules it’s tough to just go to Astoria hoping they can seat you.  I’d rather go somewhere I know I can be seated at the time I need.

I've been living in DC for five years and this is hands down the best restaurant I've ever been to in the city. The pork fried rice changed my life and the hosts & bartenders are simply fantastic people
Great vibe, cocktails and staff
Good Ford
Amazing food, good vibes, great staff.
Great cocktails. Great food. Great service. I'll be back.

Solo diner. Sat at the bar on a Monday night. Had pork fried rice and walnut shrimp, with a dark and stormy and rye old fashioned.  I arrived a little past 7. I was sat quickly. Music was playing a moody blues mashup of southern rock and British blues. It was a great compliment to the Art Deco interior and low yellow lighting.  I occupied one of the four (!) chairs at the bar - two on each end. There are no seats directly in front of the bar, which makes it feel a bit like a service bar. Tables line the wall with a narrow pathway between. There’s booths and some larger party seating (probably six at most) on either end of the restaurant.  The server was quick and nice. She gave me some recommendations and away I went.  It’s indisputable that the food here is excellent. Came out quick, hot, and generously portioned for 2 people. At $14 a pop, that’s about right. I ate my fill and had enough left over for lunch.  The drinks were also good. From my perch, I watched the female bartender churn away at all manner of libations. She was calm and efficient in her technique. Her rye old fashioned was particularly delish - nailing the spot between booze forward and sweetness with that hint of orange that makes these so drinkable. Bravo.  Several times I observed folks come out from the BoH to help clear dishes and check on guests. I think that shows a true team spirit and ownership amongst the employees. The manager should be commended for his leadership - that sort of teamwork isn’t dictated, it’s born of a common love of service that can only be nurtured in a safe environment.  All in all, an excellent experience.
Great food and drink. Exactly what you need, when you need it!
Very good food and service, but pricey

The food here is amazing, the water boiled beef is some of the best I've ever had and highly recommended! Great cocktails too. All food and drink items are $14 each which makes everything easy to ring up but also means that some food items are much better values than others. Tell the waiter/bartender what kind of drinks you like and they're great about making something specifically for your tastes. We love having this place in the neighborhood!
I had a great time with my friends. I completely forgot to take photos.

Sichuan Shenanigans!  The minute you walk in you're transported to what I can only describe as the interior of a luxury antique train.  The beautiful blue and gold really is alluring.  I like the simplicity of the menu - food items and cocktails at a flat price of $14.  BOURBON SMASH Bourbon + Lemon + Sugar + Mint = LOVE.  FAVORITES: WALNUT SHRIMP Fried shrimp tossed with a creamy honey sauce topped with candied walnuts. *this is probably the best walnut shrimp I've ever had, the shrimp was lightly battered and the honey sauce was YUMMMMM, even the crumbled walnuts were amazing  CHIMICHURRI (cold) Thinly sliced ribeye with chimichurri, chili oil, shaved celery and fennel *the ribeye was so thinly sliced it almost melted, it was so tasty with the chimichurri and chili oil  GOOD: DAN DAN NOODLES pork fat, sesame oil, sesame paste, chili oil, soy sauce, pickled mustard greens, Sichuan peppercorns, mushroom salt, crushed peanuts, fried ground pork & scallions *these were spicier than I expected but these were some tasty noodles, a little bit greasy  CHILI WONTON pork wontons topped with chili oil, cilantro and scallions *so these were just ok but I'd prob ask for some extra chili oil on the side because these are steamed and the water seeps out of the wontons and waters down the chili oil  SWEET & SOUR RIBS Fried baby back ribs in caramel, vinegar and sesame sauce *personally I'm not a big sweet and sour fan generally speaking and this was more a bit too sour for me  WATER BOILED BEEF Thinly sliced tri-tip poached in stock with celery, mustard greens, collard greens and soy bean sprouts. *reminded me of a very watery less flavorful pho  SERVICE It was really good in the beginning but then started to dwindle toward the end of service.
Love the ambiance, the food, and the drinks. Couldn’t find any faults if I tried! Definitely check this out

I'm a big fan of their other bar, Copycat, so I decided to come here for dinner on Saturday with some friends. Tried a number of the signature cocktails and food and we were pleasantly surprised with everything we got. The water boiled beef was really cool, and had a different type of spice profile than I'm used to where it sort of numbs your tongue instead of providing intense heat like some other Szechuan dishes do. The interior of the restaurant was also unique and gave it a fancy vibe.  The only complaint I have about Astoria is that the service we received was somewhat lackluster. We had a table for most of the evening and had to constantly flag waiters down to buy more drinks. Everything on the menu including food is $14 a pop which is rather expensive, and we would of spent a lot more money if the service was more attentive.  Overall worth the visit, but next time I'll be sitting at the bar.

The Copycat Co. team opened a new craft cocktail bar, Astoria, in May of this year, and I am enamored. Sichuan food and craft cocktails? Sign me up multiple times!  With only 40-some odd seats, Astoria is small but gorgeous. It's modeled after the original bar at NYC's Waldorf-Astoria. There's a very 1920s/1930s Art Deco vibe with the brass finishes, long bar with no stools, and comfy booths. My kind of place.  And while Copycat Co. specializes in dumplings and skewers, Astoria leans to the Sichuan province. Founder Devin Gong even flew to Chengdu to learn the art of Sichuan cuisine, particularly Sichuan peppercorns. Gong even found a vendor in Sichuan who ships chiles to the restaurant. His research shows in the cooking; whereas many wannabe Sichuan restaurants overheat every dish with limited thoughtfulness, Astoria's Sichuan dishes have depth and balance of flavors especially with regards to that mala (麻辣) flavor.  All food and cocktail items are $14, and the food is served family-style. We tried the dan dan noodles, chili wontons, la-zi chicken, and mapo tofu - all Sichuan favorites of mine. Tip: stir the dan dan noodles so they're evenly coated in the chili oil. Everything was delicious and exceeded my expectations. The la-zi chicken surprised me. Typically, this dish is composed of boneless chicken amid millions of dried Sichuan chili peppers. Astoria adapted this traditional dish with fried chicken wings braised with leeks in a chili, ginger, garlic sauce. It's creative and delectable.  The cocktails here are wonderful. From the bourbon smashers, Caipirinha, Moscow mules, old fashioned, daiquiris, gimlets, and painkillers, there is a vast array of cocktails to order. I particularly enjoyed Ducky Rosé, which is made with lemon, St. Germaine, pêche, and Lillet rosé. It's a lovely summer cocktail.  It's first-come, first-serve. Not a great spot for large groups (they can comfortably seat groups of six or fewer). The bar is open until 2am Sunday through Thursday and until 3am Friday-Saturday.

Feels like a Manhattan bar, with its creative use of imited space. The cocktails are unusual, but good. The bar is appealingly designed, creating a comfortable and cozy environment. The bartenders are friendly. But the fun begin when the food starts rolling out. A Sichuan delight! The chili wontons -- delicious. The lazy chicken and waterboiled beef, even better. Definitely planning a return visit.

Overly priced asian fusion fanfare. we came here to check out this newbie on the block the other night. Very much to our surprise all items on the menu were $14 in which more than half of them are starter / appetizer-like, in small quantity to be specific. We are all ethnic Chinese so neither of us thought the dishes were 'fantastic' / 'delicious' like in all the local guide's reviews. The cocktail drinks are mainstream decent. Just one sincere and honest suggestion to the owner, DROP THE PRICE to < $10 if you want to see your restaurant survive in this neighborhood. And for now, we'll stick to our favorite AGORA, next door.
Friendly staff, super cute decor, interesting and quite delicious Chinese fusion food!

It is tough trying to decide to give this place 3 or 4 stars.  I decided to give it 3 stars for the following reasons:  food quality:  5 price value: 3 service: 1  The food is pretty good but the price point is way too high for the quantity given.  We could get similar quality food at an authentic Chinese restaurant but get a portion size 2 or 3 times larger than what we received.  I am perplexed why they thought a small food dish and an alcoholic beverage should be priced the same.  Everything on their menu (all food and all drinks) is priced at $14.  I don't know if it is because we don't drink but our server gave us an attitude.  When we were done with the meal, she was so quick to get us out the door that she nearly dropped a dish on me.  I have quick reflexes so I caught it before it spilled all over me.  She grunted a quick and  insincere apology and left our table.  I am glad we gave this place a try but I am not sure if we will return.

Sister restaraunt to Copycat on H street NE.  Have to say very impressed. Decor is like a Asian fusion diner. But it feels very warm and also like you walked into some secret speakeasy. Food is very very good and drinks will hit you nicely. Nice edition to 17th street. Price point $$. Try it you will like it.
literally delicious... I have been twice in the matter of a week and want to go right back.  everything is pretty spicy so not for the meek but wow is it delicious.

Generally excellent dishes (though the mapo tofu is a little bit on the bland/unspicy side), service, and cocktails (though they're quite small). Very small/intimate, but well-designed space. Appreciate that the spicy dishes are spicier than what you'd usually find served at a restaurant that seems to cater to the general population.
way over priced... 8 wontons for $14!?!? a little bowl of fried rice was also $14!!! Please offer spoon/fork with the fried rice, very difficult to eat rice with chopsticks.
So delicious 😫😫.  And the ambience and decor are great 😫😫😫.

Wont be coming back.. the service was great and the waiters were lovely people, but I believe the food itself is mediocre, and overpriced. The Mapo Doufu was very weird, and It felt as if some ingredients were missing from the dish. I also dont understand why everything, including most of the drinks were all priced at 14$, because I think it causes a lot of misunderstanding. The owner told me that this pricing was to make everything easier, but it caused a lot of confusion in the group I was with. I also accidentally double tipped, but that was my mistake due to writing down the tip amount, before leaving it in cash.  Overall, the servers were great, but I really regret coming here otherwise.

Beautiful and cozy. Excellent atmosphere and attention to detail with the design and execution of the space. I highly suggest getting in early and getting one of the ends of the bar as it sort of acts as a sort of Chef's table. There is a table next to the kitchen to accommodate a larger group (call ahead).  At the bar you will find a very peculiar drink menu with some tiki oriented offerings and traditional craft oriented drinks on the other side. A Lieutenant Colonel is a great aged rum and spices concoction. The Cerulean city came across as a lighter and more fruity offering, while the Pikachu #2 was creamy with a dusting of cinnamon and a touch of coffee added. Eli was a real craftsman behind the bar cracking ice for each drink and prepared with all the right ingredients and knowledge.  The food offerings were a delight. The dumplings were the star of the show ladled with a great spicy oil-type dressing. The Mapotofu was excellent with a reach, deep sauce with notes of beef, five spice, and peppercorns. Beware your spice levels if you do not like heat.  All in all, a great mix of dishes and drinks without a fork to be found in sight. Highly recommended not just if you are "in the area.  Add on: just look at the new pictures
Authentic food (delicious) at an unauthentic price point (It’s quite expensive.)

Stumbled on Astoria last night. Immediately recognized it as a relation of Copy Cat, one of my favorite bars in DC.  Atmosphere was unique, energetic. Servers went above and beyond to accommodate my group. The drinks were stellar. The food made me moan.
Recommendations: the walnut shrimp—best I’ve had in DC—and the Pikachu No.2, a really fun ginger/nutmeg flavored coffee cocktail.
Great cocktails! Great food!
Love the aesthetic of this place. The drinks were delicious and while I didn’t have the food my friend raved about how flavorful the pork fried rice was. I’ll definitely be coming back!

Great bar! The owners also own a bar on H ST NE called Copy Cat, which quickly became my favorite bar when I lived in NE.  Very excited they've decided to open another bar in NW!  The space is on the small side, but has small tables by the bar and a few larger tables for groups. The cocktails are amazing, as are the bartenders. The food is also very good. Highly recommend. Gave it 4 stars just because our server wasn't very friendly, but everything else was great. Stop by if you're in the area!

If you ask bartenders where they go for a quality cocktail, they consistently say Copy Cat on H Street NE. Because of this, it's about time Copy Cat opened a sister location in a different part of town to spread the love.  Astoria DC is in Dupont Circle close to a great burger joint (Duke's Grocery) and a froyo spot (Mr. Yogato). The space itself is small, but they make good use of the space. The royal blue booths and seats make it appear very fancy, but don't be fooled. It's a casual spot for all people and the sweatpants our bartender wore proves it. It's accessible!  Everything on the menu from cocktails to dishes are $14 to make it easy. The bartenders have a list of cocktails ready to go, but I recommend doing bartender's choice. Every time I didn't regret it. I was made a Hawaii cocktail as well as a strawberry caipirinha. They have stiff options and sweet options.  The food is amazing! It's Chinese street food using simple ingredients with bold flavors. Every dish we got was out of this world, but here are they are in order of favorite to least favorite: 1) Chili wonton- it's spicy, but not too spicy, 2) Dan Dan noodles- the best in the city with a good crunch to it (sorry, Panda Gourmet), 3) water boiled beef- it's unique and VERY spicy, but made from stuff awards are given out for, and 4) pork fried rice- tasty, but not as bold as the other dishes.  Astoria will be my new go-to for date night and bro nights. It's perfect!

Super delicious chili sauce. You must get the water boiled beef. It's delicious and super flavorful. The drink menu is just like Copycat Co. And the ambiance is similar. The service was great. This my new one of my new favorite places.
Amazing cocktails, even more amazing Szechuan food! Some super spicy, some nice and balanced!

ASTORIA generates a one of a kind energy - we've crossed the globe and never experienced anyplace quite like it. More (secret) swank bar than restaurant, cocktails are artisan, and if you like Szechuan fare the walnut shrimp and lazi chicken are tasty and well prepared. The 40 or so seats were filled all evening long with both patrons and staff enjoying the scene.

If you are looking for an authentically-spiced Szechuan experience, go here. But be warned, the spice level is unforgiving for those who don't like spicy food. Get the water-boiled beef and the spicy tofu. Also, the cocktails are out-of-this-world.  10/10 would recommend.
Great cocktails, good service, and really they had me at the unlimited bowls of goldfish.

Disappointment! All dishes are very greasy and swimming in oil, overpriced. Brooklyn beer is $14, whereas nice places in Manhattan charges $8 to $10. Only 1 option of red and white wines, white wine is very sweet, $14 per glass.
Drinks, food and service on point

What an amazing bar experience in DC! Drinks are amazing and the service behind bar is entertaining and witty. Pro tip, if you sit at the bar you can likely get them to make you any drinks from Copycat (I think they are owned by the same people). Food has a unique Chinese fusion flare, both spicy and savory that will punch anyone with flavors for late night snacks.
